text:
'Right to a speedy trial' belongs to BOTH the defendant AND the public.
Criminals do not have a right to remain free forever, so they can keep committing crimes.
Criminals right to speedy trial is both to clear their name (if they care about that sort of thing, which clearly Trump does not), and to manage how long they are held in jail pending trial.  Not every defendent can afford bail or is granted bail, and without that right the state could keep a person in jail forever 'pending' trial.
Trump has a known track record of committing crimes (past convictions, settlements, decisions...) and is currently pending trial in four felony cases.  Kinda makes you guess maybe he might commit another crime one of these days while awaiting trial.  You know, like Obstruction, Witness intimidation / tampering, Jury tampering or defamation (an old favorite of his) or a scam (perhaps relating to his PAC) because he has a rich history of those, or maybe something new, because clearly he has branched out before into new areas.
So if you are going to bend over backwards and DESPITE his recent actions relating to prosecutors, judges, witnesses etc... and leave him free pending trial, then having a speedy trial does seem reasonable.
author: Douglas Archer

This case is pretty laughable coming out of Georgia where you have/had someone screaming to high heaven that her election was stolen and multiple other statements like,, the election was rigged, I won, there was voter suppression, refused to say Kemp was legitimately elected and more.  Now, of course, she's trying to distance herself from her words but the intent is the same.  I don't know if Trump is guilty or not I'm not a supporter, but I do have to side eye anyone who ran a campaign on "getting" someone because our laws aren't supposed to be usedcas a personal cudgel and it diminshes our judicial system when used that way.  Innocent until proven guilty in a court of law, we'll just have to wait until the jury decides whenever and wherever that may be and abide by that decision whether we like it or not.

text: Meadows' reasoning is totally circular: My boss ordered me to violate the Hatch Act so often I must have been a federal employee the whole time, that’s what my paycheck says anyway. His constant violations of the Hatch Act revealed in his testimony only militates against his claim of acting as the WH Chief of Staff in Georgia. The White House role in efforts to reverse the CERTIFIED Georgia election with its valid presidential electors was precluded by the fact that AG Barr, the federal election security agency and judicial review in 60 cases had already directly informed Meadows and Trump that none of falsely claimed defects in the election would alter the election outcome. The subsequent multiple acts of intimidation, extortion and fraud that Meadows and Trump perpetrated upon Georgia’s election workers, election officials, Governor, legislators and voters were prohibited by state and federal law and therefore well outside of any possible Executive Branch duties. The admission under oath that Meadows believed there were no Hatch Act boundaries in the Chief of Staff duties suggests a needed adjustment of his federal plea deal where he now disgorges his WH paychecks in addition to the 5-year RICO minimum sentence on the Georgia chain gang. “That's the sound of the men working on the chain gang. All day long I hear them singin’ uh, ah, uh ah”

text:
I think the simplest way to look at it is this: Was Donald Trump acting in his capacity as president by seeking to overturn the election results and by extension asking Meadows to take any of these actions?  The answer is simply, no.  Trump wasn't acting on behalf of the people of the United States, in fact just the opposite.  Therefore, any actions he requested of Meadows are not part of his duties as a federal employee.

And Meadows is probably lucky he's not charged with attempted bribery.  His offer of campaign money to help with recounting efforts could be viewed as a bribe if you ask me.

text: In a case of "superior orders" in the military when a low ranking soldier commits an atrocity at the direction of their superior, the most important factor is whether the solider knew he/she was committing a crime. Meadows knew he was committing a crime. Problem is he hasn't been convicted yet. The correct ruling by the judge is that it stays in state court. Either Meadows committed a crime and was not acting in his duties or he's not guilty. The case itself in state court will determine whether he was acting in his role.
author: Ian Philmore

text: The core point of the Hatch Act is that Fed employees (I was one) are paid by taxpayers. We are NOT paid to engage in political campaign activities. This is not ambiguous & is enforced throughout the services - not just in DC.  It doesn’t matter who asks you to do it - you don’t, because you work for all citizens, not a political campaign.

text:
The majority of the water from Katrina came from failed levies.   The levies failed because the winds from Katrina piled and pushed water against the levies eventually over-topping and collapsing them.

The problem with New Orleans is that is sits at the junction of the Gulf of Mexico and the Mississippi River and the entire city sits below sea level (and is sinking).   Although 10 feet above sea level isn't great, it's much different than living below sea level next to a big river and your life depends on levies.

text: Africa, a continent rich in history, culture, and natural resources, has been scarred by the legacy of colonization for centuries. The time has come for Africa to break free from the shackles of its colonial past and reclaim its rightful place on the global stage. Emancipation from colonization is not only a call for justice, but a necessary step toward realizing Africa's full potential.

text:
""French Franco Front's" downfall.❗
Last but not least, as Gabon lost its dominant role, the "French Franco Front's" backing for the appearance of "African cosmetic democracy" brought an end to it.
 
Franco Front's"  of West African States initially promoted a form of democracy in Africa that was more cosmetic than real. This allowed France to maintain its influence over West African countries even after they had gained independence. 
As a result, African leaders were more beholden to France than to their own people.❗LOL 😂

However, this situation eventually changed. A new generation of fearless leaders emerged who were committed to true democracy and sovereignty for their countries. With the support of their people, these leaders were able to overthrow the corrupt regimes that had been supported by France.

The downfall of "Franco Front's"' promotion of cosmetic democracy was a major turning point in the history of West Africa. It paved the way for a new era of democracy and self-determination for the region.
We hoped that this new era would be marked by cooperation, harmony, and remarkable achievements for the African continent.💚✌😂

text: Hope Florida will be ok! To correct a potential misinterpretation of what the presenter said: we use Categories 1-5 to describe cyclones (hurricanes) in Australia. 1 is the weakest, and 5 is the strongest. I lived in tropical north-east Australia for several years and waited out two cyclones. I remember taping the windows, cleaning up the backyard etc. Lots of wind and some water damage, but nothing too bad, thank god, because we weren't in the centre of the cyclone.

text:
Call to repair Nord Stream gas pipelines for future Russian trade relations

The state premier of Saxony, Michael Kretschmer, is advocating for the repair of the Nord Stream gas pipelines in Germany while it is still possible. Kretschmer believes that these pipelines could be crucial in the future if Germany and Russia normalize trade relations under new leadership in Moscow. The pipelines were blown up last September, but Kretschmer thinks that they should still be repaired as soon as possible to keep energy policy options open.

text:
The goal was never to cause Russia to stop producing and selling oil and gas. Removing that much supply from the market would mean there would not be enough to meet the demand. If there is not enough to go around the price goes up until enough buyers decide they can't afford it. This means without the Russian supply prices would increase substantially. To the point of crippling the world economy and causing civil unrest throughout the developed world. 

The goal is to keep Russia producing but limit the number of potential customers and keep the pricing down. Russia is free to sell oil and gas to China, India and nations friendly to Russia. The more oil and gas Russia supplies these places the less the rest of the world needs to come up with to meet the global demand. 

The west is also keeping the price that these friendly nations are paying Russia for oil and gas down by threatening to punish nations that pay more than we allow them to pay. 

It is perfectly fine for Russian oil and gas to be cheaply sold to another nation and then that product to end up in the world supply. The point is to limit the income Russia collects. We want the oil, just not to pay Russia because they are using that revenue to attack Ukraine.

The entire situation is a lot of bad options. It is a complicated mess. International law and cooperation is always messy at best. This is just how the world operates.

text: That’s the difference between sanction and embargo. So far sanctions on the price of Russian oil are content that India, for example, is buying extra Ural crude at a price about $10 barrel above cost and refining much more than it did, taking former market share away from refined Russian products (not under sanction) without any of that excess profit above the Ural crude rate going back to Russia. The figure being quoted as only $10ms is the massive reduction that the US, UK & EU have looked for in Russian hydrocarbon revenues as sanction for breaking Ukraine’s sovereignty. Embargo of all Russian oil is still possible as a further measure, but will have global consequences beyond Russia itself such as economic & political instability in other countries. If a nation, grouping or company wants to make PR capitol out “being Russian oil free” it needs to work for that and can’t just ignore source of oil, otherwise we should accept that there is a reason Russia is sanctioned in this and other trade areas by the vast majority of the United Nations and not embargoed.

text:
While I don't want to see Russia get a dime, unless I missed it, I didn't see the total scale.  We were shown the fraction of jet fuel.  But what percentage of the entire hydrocarbon market is this?  I saw figures in the 10s and 100s of Millions of dollars. Yet aren't the energy markets in the Billions of dollars?

I don't think the planners of the sanctions expected Russia to be totally isolated, just throttled.

I think the bigger issue is how many goods are getting INTO Russia.  Goods that Russia would previously directly import are now passing through a 3rd party nation before showing up in Russian markets.

Since many of those goods are dual use and can be adapted for Military use, better controls on what gets into Russia is likely more important compared to Russian hydrocarbon exports.

Russia will always be able to export hydrocarbons to nations not participating in the sanctions.  This means the market merely shuffles who gets what from whom.  Nations like India and China will take advantage of the current market and buy Russian hydrocarbons at a deep discount even if they don't refine them and re-export finished products to the rest of the world.

Instead, the architects of the sanctions need to put into place a plan to curb exports to nations that are willing to pass goods on to Russia.  I.E. if they suddenly import double, triple or more of some good compared to pre-war figures, curb the excess goods as it's likely the importer didn't suddenly have a 500% increase in demand for Western made washing machines or candy bars, or whatever.

text: Russians  are attacking Ukrainian weapons depots and army barracks while Zelenskyy is attacking residential buildings with anti-aircraft missiles with long expired shelf life. Zelenskyy already hit Poland, Romania (a jet and a chopper were downed, 8 servicemen killed), Moldova, Belarus, numerous residential buildings and at least two children’s playgrounds inside Ukraine with these missiles. Western missiles which are sent there are also with either expired shelf life or very close to expiration date.   It’s mindboggling how many buildings were hit and civilians killed (including two hapless Polish farmers) with this ongoing criminal lunacy of Zelenskyy regime. The chance of downing Russian missile is negligible in comparison with a risk of an accident with numerous civilian casualties. To give weapons to this war criminal Zelenskyy is like giving matches and gasoline to a serial  arsonist.

text:
400 thousand heroes". The Ukrainian operator Kyivstar accidentally admitted to the real losses of the Armed Forces of Ukraine. The operator launched a charity event - send a message with the word "thank you" to the number of a fallen soldier. “400,000 heroes will never answer the phone again,” they wrote in the promo. The video has now been removed.
Total mobilization coming in Ukraine: One of the main problems of the Ukrainian Army are the horrific losses on the battlefields. The meat grinder assaults during the months-long counteroffensive did not bring any significant victories, and the combat-ready units of the Armed Forces were ground down on the battlefield. In order to continue any effective military operations, Kyiv needs to increase mobilization throughout the country. At first, the German media reported that Ukraine needs to mobilize about 3 million people to win the war. Such reports were widely appreciated as a kind of instruction to Kyiv from NATO.

However, according to various estimates, a total of no more than 10 million people remain in the country, and combat-ready aged men are already either at the front, in graves or have fled abroad. Kiev is unlikely to find the necessary number of new fighters. At the same time, the West has to find additional funds to provide them with training, food, weapons and payroll.

Nevertheless, Kiev is already preparing the public for total mobilization. In February 2022, the Ukrainian authorities announced a general mobilization in the country. At the end of August, Zelensky said that the General Staff was asking for “an opportunity to mobilize more servicemen.” The Head of the National Security Council made similar statements. Despite attempts to calm the population, mass mobilization continues throughout the country. Men are forcibly caught on the streets or in public places and enlisted in the military against their will. This often leads to clashes with civilians. Military commissars beat off women and children trying to save their loved ones.

The public anger is growing. Ukrainian military commissars have become the targets. In the Transcarpathian region, a sergeant who caught men and sent them to a meat grinder on the frontlines was found with a broken skull in the forest.

With or without any official public statement, Kyiv is preparing for a new wave of mass mobilization in autumn. All employees of military enlistment offices and military medical commissions were taken under tight control and banned from issuing deferrals and permits to leave the country. Pro-Russian hackers have published documents confirming that the military authorities have already obliged local state and commercial enterprises to provide lists of all their employees who are fit for duty.

What is the most important is that Kyiv is mobilizing the population of the eastern and southern regions, which Kyiv nationalists in power consider to be widely pro-Russian. According to the documents, preparations for large-scale mobilization are being carried out in the Chernihiv, Sumy, Kharkiv, Dnipropetrovsk, Odessa, Zaporozhye and Mykolaiv regions.

These are the regions that the Kyiv regime is considering to be lost. First, their population will be ground down in the assaults, then, they can be destroyed by hostilities.

text: Has anyone investigated legacy admissions and/or nepotism in the US military too?  For instance, the late Senator John McCain came from a Navy family, was admitted to the US Naval Academy and got on the coveted naval aviator career trajectory.  The US military seems to proclaim that it's a meritocracy but maybe not so much?  Or maybe it's more that military families pass on a willingness to serve in the armed forces to their children.  And they know how to navigate the bureaucracy to get the better assignments.
author: John Lee

text: I agree with this 100%. Universities should eliminate legacy preference from their admissions process. But I wonder how the NYT Opinion section feels about affirmative action. text:
And yet they all checked the box. Every single one of them checked the box.

I'm glad they're speaking up now but it would be so much better if legacy students didn't check the box. They probably wouldn't have gotten in without it. 

I used my privilege but now I want to make sure that others don't do the same. What happens when it's time for your kids to apply and you want to ensure them a successful career? Will you tell them not to check the box? How will you explain to them that you did?

text:
The idea that this song was pushed to the top by right-wing influencers does not make any sense. Right-wing influencers have tried to push other songs to the top, as well, but none has attracted this volume of attention. If this song has attracted this much attention, it is because of the song itself, not because it was pushed by right-wing influencers. Right-wing influencers may have attracted attentions to the song, but if the song didn’t have any merit in itself, it would never fly to the top of the charts like this. You have gone to a great length to create a complicated narrative, which is really a form of conspiracy theory, to explain why this song went viral. How about a simple explanation: it is a great song and people love it. As simple as that.  When you create a narrative, please don’t let your personal feelings influence your narrative. Instead, stick to logic and the truth, even if you personally don't like it.
I must add that I personally do not sympathize with right-wing ideology at all and to refute your theory, I first heard about this song, not from right-wing influencers on social media, but in a Guardian article titled: "The protest song that's taken America by storm hits too many false notes". Then I checked the song and loved it because it is beautiful. And one other thing to give you some context, I was not able to listen to Jason Aldean or Luke Combs or Morgan Wallen songs even once. I played ten seconds from each song and stopped. Oliver Anthony's music is different.

text: Hey everyone I’m Johnny, one of the producers of this Opinion Video. I’ve been hearing about the potential collapse of American democracy but I’ve always been really unsatisfied with the explanations of what’s actually happening. It’s a discourse that’s become fully politicized to the point where I didn’t really know what to believe. That’s why I teamed up with The New York Times editorial board member Michelle Cottle to get to the bottom of what’s really threatening American democracy and how scared we should really be. Working with Michelle, I started to see a different threat to democracy taking shape, one that goes beyond voter suppression and to the heart of our electoral system. I'd love to know what you think about our film, and if, like me, you're seeing the danger to our democracy in a whole new light.
author: Johnny Harris

text: The laws the red states have passed are not voter "suppression".  Shrinking the time to submit certain ballots, having less drop boxes, having to show your ID, not having snacks while in line, etc. are not things that "suppress" voters.  Suppressing would mean stopping people from voting, which isn't happening.  Synonyms of suppress are conquer, vanquish, defeat and crush.  These laws are designed to streamline voting, not eliminate voting.  With these laws in place, all the same people have the right to vote, they simply need to vote within the guidelines of their state, which is not hard to do unless one is incompetent, and in that case, they probably shouldn't be voting anyway.  As the video points out, these laws actually help Democrats.  They aren't providing barriers to Democrats.  If they were providing barriers, those barriers would affect ALL voters, not just one party.  And the ridiculous conspiracy theory this video is putting out there will never happen.
author: Chris Harmon

text: As someone watching this outside the US. If you are watching this, and are able to. You should get involve at the local level, for protecting democracy for sake of your country and the world. author: José Ricardo Campos Mora

text: This is so sad. I used to be a committee person in Philly, which required me to work my local precinct voting location. We had two Democrats and two Republicans who were committee people and we worked outside the location observing and offering campaign literature and assistance to any voter who needed it. Inside, we had 4 lovely non-partisan workers who ran the actual voting process. I can remember many of them working there all the way back when I was in pre-school and would go with my mom to vote. Its a tedious 13 hour day but we all showed up for the elections twice a year and were proud to participate in the process. At the end of the night, they print 3 copies of the results. The Republican committee people take their copy back to their Ward Leader. The Dems take their copy back to their Ward Leader. And one of the election workers takes the 3rd copy down to City Hall. Our Ward leaders tally up the Ward-wire results and call them into the head of their respective parties. Then the heads of the parties confirm their tallies match the tallies of the Election Commissioners at City Hall. We felt proud to serve each election day as citizens who bear witness to make sure the voting process goes smoothly, no one is wrongly disenfranchised, and work together cooperatively across party lines to make sure we had an accurate tally.

text: In greece, the votes are counted exclusively by lawyers (barristers, state attorneys, prosecutors) who are appointed in each voting center by the Supreme Court after application . Then the President of each local Court regulates the whole procedure and has the public servants of the Court re-check all the data provided by the lawyers. There are no complaints whatsoever and even if there someone wants to challenge the counting, he can easily address the Special Elections Court, which can judge the case effectively  due to the data provided by the local Court themselves. This system is  expensive due to the reimbursement of the lawyers (1000 euros per election to 20000 lawyers) but is completely corrupt-free, which is amazing for the greek standards.

text: Why on earth would corporations get ‘credit’ or compensation for the carbon removal of forests? Trees plant themselves, and were deforested already. It is a double standard, because they did not account for the removal of carbon sinks, the emissions already released, or the cost of a larger economy. It is saying there is economic value in nature, but it was free to extract and destroy to the point of catastrophe, but now restoring or foregoing further destruction will be counted as a credit which justifies further extraction and destruction. Nature is not capital, it is a living system. It cannot be treated like a bank with deposits and withdrawals. Plus, market growth rates and emission rates are logarithmic, they will double every few years. And atmospheric carbon is persistent, it compounds. But natural systems are organic systems that seek equilibrium, within the limits of physical constraints. They are resilient until the moment they collapse. Economic growth is not possible to reach zero emissions because net emissions will not be zero if they grow. Do economists not understand climate science, or are they purposefully misrepresenting reality?

I'm no corporate apologist and I do want to see businesses do their part, so I'm going to keep supporting these commitments while demanding results from them.

text: Most of this companies buy what are called "carbon credits". These are certificates given to renewable energy producers for each kWh produced. The thing is that Google or any of these companies do not offset anything, they keep polluting and then they just pay some solar energy company for the clean energy they produced to get credit for it.
author: David CJ Photography

text:
This issue is the same as our recycling issue. We preach the usual "Reduce, Reuse, Recycle" thing over and over again. But read that again. What do you see us doing 99% of the time? Just recycling. A little reusing here and there, and no reducing.

The solution here is simple. We don't continue to put emissions out at increasingly large rates while saying we'll fix it later. **We reduce the emissions where they start.** This means companies using more expensive, but cleaner methods of transport for delivering goods, us not buying as many throwaway products whose supply chains produce carbon emissions, and us investing in technologies like artificial meats & materials to reduce our emissions globally. Unfortunately, cutting back on anything is hard for us.

text: We should not be overwhelmed with the amount of work needed to restore forests.  With 8 billion people in the world, 2.5 billion trees is not too much if we each develop that habit to plant trees.  Besides, biology is on our side as well. Many processes necessary for growing thick vegetation are automated by the earth's natural processes with all its army of interlinked microbes, insects, and animals.  All we have to design is how to kickstart the soil again to be more nutritious and productive.  We should push towards reclaiming vast desert lands, bury there key organic wastes that could restore soil nutrition, and then plant starter vegetation that could then develop into forests.  What's wrong with reforestation efforts is they fail to consider the value of biodiversity and instead employ somewhat monoculture methods or just a few species to cover wide areas.  There are small time entrepreneurs that already developed some technology how to more quickly grow forests even at your backyard in a shorter time... This could be tapped and scaled by governments.

text:
Now that I'm aware of all the crap he (Elvis) went through trying to do what he loved... I wish he never signed on with that dude (Hank's character). He would have been big no matter what. He probably would have still gotten in trouble with his non-fans and been shipped off to bootcamp.. but if he was free of that slimey, narcissistic POS, he would have done much more of what he loved, the way he wanted to do it.

I felt sad / feel sad knowing he spent so much time being pushed around, used, and made to do performances he hated -- time he'd never get back.

I'm not an Elvis-music fan -- not my style and long before my time -- but watching this movie made him seem real. Emotional. Relateable.

I feel like the music industry and greedy, selfish management killed him.

text:
I can’t imagine women suddenly losing control against their will at the sight of Elvis. Like why would they be unconscious of their excitement. The girls who screamed and was shocked by it was so weird like, “oh my did I just scream?” I call bs ngl

Edit (because people are assuming): I didn't mean women can't get hysterical over male artists. I'm just saying it's odd to be unconscious of it. Like when I get excited I wouldn't scream suddenly and be shocked by my actions as if I had no control over what I did. I just feel like it undermines women's autonomy because they got excited *against their will* and they were *unconscious of actions they purportedly couldn't control*.

text: liked the movie but since it was hollywood there were many inacuracies. I could point out many other scenes that werent accurate but doesn't matter, it was still entertaining. I saw Elvis on tv as a 9 yr old on Ed Sullivan show September 9, 1956...it was after that, not after Steve Allen hound dog Bs that he said those people in NY not going to change me none in that Tupelo day to celebrate Elvis...Maybe there was some legal reason why no mention of Ed Sullivan or Elvis performance not mentioned but after the 3rd time in January 1957..Ed Sullivan said sometrhing like "of all the big names we've ever had this young man is truly ok"..that endorsment meant a lot to playing down Elvis girations that enraged parents and clergemen...anyway sorry to bore you...

text: This scene was incredibly dumb, but also the best scene in the entire film. It's impossible the deer didn't notice the dinosaur earlier. That deer should have run off BEFORE you see the dino, to indicate something dangerous was approaching. Since the dino is blind, it doesn't see Claire hanging from the tree. She's safe. So why does she unbuckle herself and fall to the ground, making a ton of noise? Did she want to get eaten? It makes zero sense that someone paralyzed with fear would do that. And then she goes into water, which is very loud and easy to pinpoint movement in, and somehow the dino doesn't just dip his face into the water to bite around and find her? Oh and how did the dino see the deer in the first place?? It was being perfectly silent, just like Claire. Is it only able to see deer or something? I hated this stupid movie

text: In a funny sort of way, despite looking cool, this shot actually perfectly summarises what is so wrong with this film. Why would a giant herbivore bat a deer away like that, why would the deer not see/hear/smell it coming, why would the creature slowly chase her crawling along the ground, why would she think to slowly crawl away while being in plain sight, why would it scream at some water. It's all a lot of solid film craft for the sake of an utterly ridiculous scene. Jurassic park may not be exactly realistic but the original film played with basic ideas that made some sense.

text: Majority of woman who seek abortions were on a type of contraceptive that failed them, 60% already mothers. This is just prolonging the abortion time, majority of abortions happen BY week 7, now because of all the hurtles woman are now having them BY week 13, and that’s not because they are choosing too.  It’s especially effecting the woman who HAVE to keep the pregnancy because they can’t find ways threw all the new hurtles. (Examples: Finding a ride for travel, Finding time off work, Finding child care, Having enough to pay all expenses, etc.) So many people don’t get that even for woman who WANT to be pregnant might need abortions, and if it’s needed in the 3rd trimester are emergencies and are RARE. Having abortion accessible for ALL won’t stop woman from having baby’s, there is no shortage, there are plenty in the system but I’ve always heard people shout it’s about life, well yes the mothers life, the millions of baby’s and children in the systems life’s, it’s unrealistic to assume majority of woman are both physically and mentally 100% healthy and capable of going threw with a pregnancy. (Also financially counts) The reality is all woman have their own individual health issues, forcing pregnancy on the hopes that they will be put up for foster care is insulting and immoral since you are risking the mothers life and well being and putting a fetus over her. Woman are more important than a fetus, if it wasn’t for her the fetus couldn’t be there in the first place. If the woman lives she still is the option to have a pregnancy in the future, but if the choice to abortion is taken that will rise the mortality rates killing both woman and fetus saving no one in the process, another thing hysterectomy’s might see a huge rise as there is 0 chance of having any pregnancy after that. These insane laws are actually pushing more woman to choose between dying or giving up the option to conceive ever again and that’s what will really bring down the numbers in population. Abortions save life’s, nobody is helping woman by taking away abortion access. This IS about woman, I don’t see why the argument is always “what about the fetuses life” well the fetus doesn’t get a say over the woman, it’s common sense, the topic is abortion, not when life begins or if the fetus is a human, because I’ll state this now, From a biological standpoint, a fetus is human only in species. It is not a viable human being until a certain gestational age, others say not until it is born (yes it’s a fact that doctors have deemed a baby already born as non viable and usually they don’t survive past a couple hours/days). To address when life begins well some people say “a new human being is formed at conception” That is just their opinion and has no facts behind it, even science doesn’t know when life actually starts. It is long pointed out that understanding what it is to be human requires a lot more than biology. And scientists can’t establish when a fertilized cell or embryo or fetus becomes a human being. The overall point is that biology does not determine when human life begins. It is a question that can only be answered by appealing to our values, examining what we take to be human. text:
Many people say abortion is 'all about the woman because it's her choice and her body'...I'm a middle aged woman who over 25 years ago chose abortion because I believed it was my right and choice. As I am writing this emotionally from my heart, I can honestly say yes, it was a one time choice for me but the depression, guilt and mental health crisis from that decision has privately haunted me for many years since. These feelings are not because someone 'shamed me', it's because privately in my conscience I knew it was wrong. My catholic faith and the sacrament of reconciliation has been healing for me. I do believe that God has forgiven me and yet, honesty till this day, in tears I know I still struggle sometimes to forgive myself.  I know I am not alone in this suffering because as evidenced by the many support groups that help post abortive women like myself. This is why I am speaking up in hopes it will help someone else one day. I am a flawed person and don't consider myself better than anyone else but I am thankful for my faith and that God exist because it has helped me slowly change my lifestyle, as well as find peace, inspiration and healing. I wish that for others too.
There is a beautiful passage in the Bible where God tells the prophet Jeremiah in Jeremiah 1:5 that “Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, before you were born I set you apart;     I appointed you as a prophet to the nations.” Every baby in the womb is a miraculous creation and if raised according to God's will, can have a beautiful, inspiring, purpose filled life. We all have a special calling in this world. Let's stop destroying and build each other up. If you don't believe that Bible verse from Jeremiah is true, then watch this video (Christ is truly God and does exist and there is more to life than what meets the eye):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d7KVNqLZkME&t=336s

text:
I've found it disgusting how the response to the pandemic of Johnson and his government was reported.

It was literally a situation like something from a movie. An imminent pandemic of unknown proportions was about to hit. We saw it creeping rapidly across Asia and then Europe. Images of Italys hospitals being totally overwhelmed with death, and what was their response?

Rubbing their hands together, "Right me old boys, looks like the markets are about to make some big changes... so how can we make as much money as possible from all this?..."

That was before they started using emergency powers to hemorrhage money into their friends companies, which they had told them to create from their laptop the week before, with no care as to if health contracts could actually be fulfilled. They even moved the infected into care homes intentionally, after receiving their own report results confirming that care homes were especially vulnerable. Meanwhile, literally untold amounts of death and suffering hit the country. 

So many of these despicable excuses for humans should be in prison, but they are being allowed to get away with it like it was nothing and normal.

text:
This reporting only slightly misses the mark, because while Gender Affirming Care does include medical interventions such as hormone therapy and adult surgery, the core of gender affirming care is the use of correct pronouns, the allowing of children to dress how they want to, and calling them by their preferred name. This gender affirming care in the home, coupled with talk therapy, is the bulk of what most people receive, and this is what the new and proposed laws also prohibit.
To be clear, these laws make it illegal to allow biologically male children to play dress up in princess costumes, they push the limit on allowing female children to wear pants, they make it illegal to call your child a nickname, and they require mandatory reporters, like your child's therapist, doctor, and teachers, to report you for child abuse if you allow this type of care in your home.

text:
Look at all that concrete that was probably once lovely fields, next to a clean river. It isn't just the urban waste produced by these houses but the now lack of natural drainage that this land once had! 

So Let me get this right, Rishi is throwing money at foreign owned water companies that manage our whole networks in the UK to sort out existing problems, let alone new ones that they are creating by building these ugly houses that normal families can't afford. 

They show a family of 5 kids. Like who can really afford to have 5 kids nowadays plus a mortgage? Who will these homes really be for? Not the homeless that were born here and waiting for a place to live for years. 

They just passed through rejected plans through appeal to build 14- 16 storey flats that is built next to a tiny stream that goes underground for miles. It has fish, shrimp and other wildlife like herons that nest there. This is also on a high flood risk plain that already floods. The boast of panoramic views, which is ironic for us folk who already live here and grow veg and rely on that daylight. 

I also wonder how much more noise it would create in a conservation area? It has already got noisier since they have started. A lot of the debated happened during covid, where no one could attend or voice their objections. 

That guy is talking absolute bs! We need the water infrastructure in place to take that waste water, away from rivers and streams and put into proper sewage treatment facilities. All of that nitrate and phosphorus can be used in creating fertilisers.

Once it leaves the private property, the responsibility is down to the water companies, who probably don't even live here enough to give a damn about what happens to the waste. It is like they almost want us to go back to the days of open waste gulleys like they have in undeveloped countries.  

Rishi has thrown money at France to stop the didgy boats and target the people traffickers. This is clearly not working. He bought a barge to house illegal migrants but didn't think to test the water on board and check for tampering before boarding these people to stay. That whole Rwanda thing, where is the proof of money well spent? 

We just received our water bill and it doesn't even state the meter reading they are using compared to actual reading as they haven't checked in months.  What made me go huh?, was there was a section on how much money i can save by redirecting my waste water into natural recourses... You mean like our local stream, with fish, shrimp, birds and other wildlife????? 

Just like the energy companies, the service charges have also gone up extranomically! 

I think more people will start to think for themselves, if a) nothing has improved over the coming winter months, that these water and b) energy suppliers don't announce new stations to cope with the new housing and ever increasing climate change.
